Description: Hollow terracotta fragment of a figure leaning on an altar pier with mouldings at top and bottom. The figure is likely Harpocrates, however, only the hand survives. The face of the pier was decorated, but is now worn and fragmentary. Possibly originally decorated. Above the pier is drapery and a child's hand. Mould-made. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Common Harpocrates figure type, commonly dated to the Roman and Ptolemaic periods. The context (late 3rd to early 1st century BC), if correct, agrees with Bailey's dating of a parallel (2008, no. 3083; EA27333; see also Török 1995, no. 78). However, others date this type to the Roman period (Dunand 1990, nos 149-51). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Rome.
Bibliographic references: Leonard 2001 / Ancient Naukratis: Excavations at a Greek Emporion in Egypt, Part II: The excavations at Kom Hadid. (p. 173, no.17 pl. 3.15.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.032) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: pl. 3.15, p. 173. no.17 (catalogue number)
